reviewText: John Garfield and Geraldine Fitzgerald strike genuine sparks in this story of a con man falling in love with his intended victim. Now who could not want Geraldine Fitzgerald. I've never been all that much for Garfield but not many could  have played his part as well. In any case, film noir lovers need this one.

reviewText: For the most part, NOBODY LIVES FOREVER (1946), a crime film starring John Garfield as a confidence man, who is also a wounded World War II Army vet, and Geraldine Fitzgerald as a rich, beautiful widow he plans to fleece, is quite enjoyable. Although its title is not a good "fit" as far as its ending is concerned, to explain why would mean providing several "spoilers."Furthermore, in my judgment the film's ten-second ending is a bit too quick or abrupt, but offsetting this are a great many earlier scenes and sequences that are very well developed and very well filmed. One cinematic feature I gradually noticed and enjoyed is that the director, Jean Negulesco, often "inched" into a scene by following several people moving in one direction and then, as another pair or group moved past in the opposite direction, by following these new people with the camera, and finally focusing on the main people in the scene, who also were moving in a different direction. This sort of slow "Z-movement" camera work impressed me favorably, as did most of the dialogue in this film's better-than-average script by W. R. Burnett.Other members of this film's excellent cast include Walter Brennan, George Tobias, and George Coulouris as well-differentiated members of the group plotting to relieve the widow of $100,000 or more of her cash. Suspense is generated when half of this group, totally as expected, defects and kidnaps the widow in order to increase their own share of the take, and the response of the other half of the group is, for the most part, clever and highly satisfying for viewers.By coincidence, after viewing NOBODY LIVES FOREVER, later the same day I happened to re-watch John Garfield and Joan Crawford in HUMORESQUE (also 1946; also directed by Jean Negulesco) on Turner Classic Movies (cable TV). Although professional reviewers have rated HUMORESQUE very highly, I found its acting often implausible and its story arc both unpleasant and unsatisfying. In my judgment, NOBODY LIVES FOREVER is much, much better.
summary: DESPITE ITS MISLEADING TITLE, THIS IS A VERY ENJOYABLE CRIME FILM

reviewText: "Nobody lives Forever" is a 1946 black and white romantic crime drama starring John Garfield, Walter Brennan, and Geraldine Fitzgerald with George Tobias, George Coulouris, and Faye Emerson. Based on an original screenplay by famed crime writer W.R.Burnett ("Little Caesar", "Beast of the City", "High Sierra", "This Gun for Hire", "Asphalt Jungle", Scarface") the story centers on a group of grifters, one of whom (Garfield) fall in love with his mark (Fitzgerald), much to the dismay of his fellow gangsters (Coulouris).Ruggedly handsome John Garfield (1913-52) was the original "method" actor. Garfield made his screen debut in 1938 in "Four Daughters" for which he received his first Best Supporting  Actor nomination. One year later "They Made me a Criminal" propelled him into the A list. He's best known for "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (1946). Blacklisted in the communist scare of the early 50s, his career was cut short, and he died in 1952 at age 39. This film comes at the height of his popularity and it was his chance to show a wider range of acting skill, which he does.Beautiful Geraldine Fitzgerald (1913-2005) plays the rich widow whom Garfield intends to fleece. She's best known for her Oscar nominated role in "Wuthering Heights" (1939)Walter Brennan (1894-1974) plays Garfield's old friend. Brennan won 3 Oscars for Best Supporting Actor  -"Come and Get it" (1936), "Kentucky" (1938), and "The Westerner" (1941) - and was nominated for his work in "Sergeant York" (1941). We know him best for his Emmy nominated role in the TV series "The Real McCoys", and his film comedies ("The Over the Hill Gang") or as the grumpy side kick Stumpy in "Rio Bravo", but he was equally capable of playing the villain, as he showed in "The Westerner" (1940), "My Darling Clementine" (1946), and again In "How the West Was Won" (1962).George Tobias (1901-1980) plays the comic relief sidekick. He appeared in more than 50 films including "The Strawberry Blonde" (1941), "Yankee Doodle Dandy" (1942), and "Passage to Marseille" (1944). Like many other film actors, he transitioned to TV in the 50s and is best remembered for his comedy as the witch Samantha's neighbor Abner on "Bewitched" (1964-71).Glamorous Faye Emerson (1917-1983) achieved her fame on TV in the 50s, but she had an active film career and worked with Garfield in films like "Between Two Worlds" (1944) and "Out of the Fog" (1941). She plays Garfield's ex-girlfriend.This was the fifth film for director Jean Negulesco (1900-93) who went on to earn an Oscar nomination for "Johnny Belinda" (1955) and win a BAFTA for "How to Marry a Millionaire" (1959). He specialized in films that take place in Europe ("Three Coins in a Fountain", "Boy on a Dolphin", "Britannia Mews") and also was known for his atmospheric use of the camera - neither of which are present here.The film is often referred to as "film noir" which it clearly isn't. There is no femme fatale (although Emerson's role had the potential) and there is no downbeat ending. The big city backdrop is substituted for the beaches of Malibu, and the sunshine replaces the dark rainy street scenes.Bottom line - an OK film from the mid 40s, with a good performance from John Garfield.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bristling drama about an East-coast confidence-man who, unfortunately, falls for the rich widow he's trying to fleece. John Garfield [Oscar-nominated for FOUR DAUGHTERS, 1938,  and BODY AND SOUL, 1947] plays the shyster who starts to feel the heat when local thugs, who actuated the project,  get restless at his inability to consummate the con with alacrity. Geraldine Fitzgerald [also Oscar-nominated for WUTHERING HEIGHTS, 1939] plays the classy but naive widow. Walter Brennan plays Garfield's down-on-his-luck old pal who gets him connected in L.A. Vet George Tobias lightens things up a bit as Garfield's easygoing, insouciant but loyal sidekick. A nice surprise by director Jean Negulesco [JOHNNY BELINDA, 1948, and the original TITANIC, 1953] with his offbeat but perceptive selection of vet British actor George Coulouris as the main villan. Coulouris, whose career will go from apex [CITIZEN KANE, 1941] to abyss [THE WOMAN EATER, 1958], is memorable as the restless and irascible, has-been mastermind, desperate to get back on top,  who can't seem to keep his nose out of the kitchen.  With that cadaverous countenance---almost gaunt and pallid with sunken eyes---and his paroxysmal paranoid-driven irritabilities and intrusions,  Coulouris' persona keeps us glued through most of the film. It's his project but he needs Garfield's funds, face and finesse to implement it with $uccess. Garfield, one of Hollywood's great, just-about-forgotten actors of the golden era, is terrific, as always. Negulesco's direction is superb as evidenced by getting every protagonist in this film firing on all cylinders, with one noteable scene---Garfield making up his mind about whether to accept the project in a backroom---a striking example of beautiful acting choreography by Garfield and his little-known supports. Predictable ending but always a joy to watch a master like Garfield getting it done.
summary: JOHN GARFIELD: FORGOTTEN TITAN OF AMERICAN CINEMA
